results.title: Harold
results.creator_credit: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Marion Crooke and Flying Carpet Films
results.brief_description: Harold Blair was considered a curiousity at the height of his career as a tenor in the 1940’s. As an Aboriginal, raised on a Reserve, Harold sang songs he had learned from watching Nelson Eddy films, or the classic operatic arias, although later in his career, the music of his own people formed part of his repertoire. Harold Blair’s life is revealed in this documentary through the people who shared his life and influenced his career; chiefly his wife and family. This is an intensly personal and frank look at an Aboriginal pioneer who had to struggle to achieve success and to reconcile his ‘stage persona’ with his Aboriginal identity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Marion Crooke and Flying Carpet Films

results.title: Australian aborigines: living off the land
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and A I F
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land. This film shows how aborigines live on native animals and plants.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: everything from nature
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Our reliance on manufactured goods is contrasted with the aborigines’ ability to use natural materials around them, which gives rise to a marked respect for their adaptability and sensitivity to the environment. Taked during an expedition by Sydney University to Arnhem Land in 1952.

results.title: From sand to celluloid
results.creator_credit: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: An impressive collection of Australian short films by Indigenous filmmakers which explore the history and contradictions of Aboriginal identity. Richard Frankland’s “No Way to Forget” is the story of a young man, working on the Royal Commission on Black Deaths in Custody, who drives home to Melbourne and is haunted by the ghosts of the dead. dead. In Sally Riley’s “Fly Peewee Fly!”, a young boy teaches his white grandmother and his Koorie father a few lessons on perspective. Rima Tamou’s “Round Up” is a tender story about two country boys who discover that their racial differences are not so acute when they are confronted with the multiculturalism and subcultures of the inner-city. In “Two Bob Mermaid” Darlene Johnson presents a beautifully filmed story about a young girl who can pass for white in a racially divided 1957 Australia. Warwick Thornton’s “Payback” presents a surreal story of a young convict who has to obey tribal lore as much as he does white law. Bill McCrow’s “Black Man Down” explores the need for contemporary Aborigines to be aware of the lessons and spirituality of the past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Vacant possession
results.creator_credit: Margot Nash, John Winter, Australian Film Commission, As If Productions and Wintertime Films
results.brief_description: Following her mother’s death, Tessa returns to Australia and to her family home, a sun bleached weatherboard adjacent to Botany Bay. She confronts the collected debris of memory; the fears, the tears and the spectre of the father who forced her flee. Tessa’s home is close to that of an Aboriginal family she knew as a child. During her 20 year absence the nation has changed but not that house. In confronting her father, both the real and the remembered amidst the remains of the old home, the past and present collide in a maelstrom of unexpected ramifications. A brooding and atmospheric piece of cinema, Margot Nash’s first feature is an ambitious drama addressing hearth and place, rememberance and regret in a contemporary setting. Starring Pamela Rabe, John Stanton, Toni Scanlon, Linden Wilkinson, Rita Bruce and Olivia Patten.

results.title: Walking together; Talkin' business; Making things right
results.creator_credit: Lew Griffiths and Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation
results.brief_description: These three programs and a kit aim to support the Council of Aboriginal Reconciliation’s vision for a united Australia “which respects this land of ours; values Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage and provides justice and equity for all.” ‘Walking together’ and ‘Talkin’ Business’ highlights the aims and operation of the Council and ‘Making things right’ discusses the implications of the Mabo decision.
results.title_for_label: Walking together; Talkin’ business; Making things right

results.title: When dreaming paths meet
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing and Community Services and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description: This program aims to promote Cross-Cultural Awareness and explores situations in which the actions of Aboriginal people have been misinterpreted by non-Aboriginal people in a work environment. Three scenarios highlight body language differences in a youth custody situation, bereavement issues and community relations. At the conclusion of each scene, Richard Frankland summarises and discusses pro-active measures that can be implemented to prevent such Cross-Cultural problems occurring in the future. Designed to be used by non-Aboriginal professionals to promote an understanding of cultural issues.

results.title: Lord of the bush
results.brief_description: Lord Alistair McAlpine, entrepreneur and Treasurer of Margaret Thatcher’s Conservative Party is opening Broome for Tourism. Examines the issues that have been raised including Aboriginal land rights and the conflict between tourist developments and conservation. Interviews colourful Broome identities and their reactions to the changes.

results.title: Beating about the bush
results.creator_credit: Caroline Sherwood, Nicholas Adler and Titus Films
results.brief_description: The film follows the tour of Djaambi, a half Aboriginal, half white, urban band from Melbourne, under the leadership of Richard Frankland as they travel to remote Aboriginal communities in outback Australia. It explores the cultural mix within the band and the culture shock all members of the band, particularly the Aboriginal members, experience as they meet another, very different side of their culture. Towards the end of the tour the various problems and cultural confusions become focused in a radical split between the white film makers and the more vocal Aboriginal band members. A disturbing look at good intentions gone wrong.

results.title: Out of darkness
results.brief_description: Robyn Williams narrates this history of the Aborigines in Australia and the archaeological discoveries that have pieced together this history. Until the 1960’s it was thought that the Aborigines had only been here 10,000 years, but discoveries made since then have pushed this timespan as far back as 50,000 years. The predecessors of the modern Aborigines had a sophisticated culture during the ice age, making Aboriginal culture the longest surviving culture in the world.
